Even when I was recovering in Walter Reed, I was determined to fly again and I wasn’t going to let anyone take that away from me. Thank you to the Wright Brothers, to Katharine Wright, and to everyone who made flight possible. pic.twitter.com/YfbA4FSXDw
I fell in love with flying in the military. I worked hard, logged more simulation hours than anyone in my class & was one of only three selected to learn how to fly a Blackhawk.

The youngest & only one to graduate college, Katharine helped run the family bicycle shop that funded their adventures, supported Orville when he suffered a nearly fatal accident & was an ambassador-like figure in Europe & America.

115 yrs ago this week, the Wright Brothers launched their 1st successful flight, paving the way for millions to discover the thrill of piloting a plane – or a helicopter! Many don’t know this but they were assisted by a heroine who does not receive the recognition she deserves.

I can’t begin to imagine what it would’ve been like to have to decide between going hungry and having my mother at home, but that’s the choice other families may have to make if Trump’s proposal gets implemented.
The goal of his new rule is clear: to vilify immigrants, scaring them away from getting the care they desperately need in an attempt to push—even starve—them out of this country.
Right now, POTUS is trying to change the law to force immigrant families to choose b/w staying eligible for perm. residency & receiving lifesaving public benefits like SNAP & Medicaid.

In the end, we survived. We scraped by. And my mother was able to join us (later becoming a proud U.S. citizen). But if President Trump has his way, the same might not be true for countless other scared, struggling families.
I still remember going to the grocery store and counting out our last five $1 food stamps to buy as much bread and bologna as possible—then praying we’d have enough to last the week.

Having a warm meal at night quickly went from being a given to a godsend. I still remember the hours my dad spent walking from payphone to payphone, hoping to find enough spare change for me and my brother to be able to afford the 25-cent school lunch the next day.

When I was a teenager, my dad lost his job, sending our family spiraling into poverty. My father, brother and I soon moved from SE Asia to Hawaii—but my mom was forced to stay back as she wasn’t yet a U.S. citizen
As the daughter of an immigrant and someone who depended on food stamps to survive, I refuse to stay silent as the Trump Admin tries to punish immigrant families by changing the “Public Charge” rule.
